subject: XenAPI: OVS agent updates the wrong port with Neutron
commit_message:
XenAPI: OVS agent updates the wrong port with Neutron

With xen hypervisor, it will create two sets of port/interface
for each VM vif: One is named as tapx.y which is qemu-emulated
NIC and is used when no PV drivers installed with the VM; The
other one is named as vifx.0 which is the xen network frontend
NIC and is used when VM has PV drivers installed. But neutron
only handle one port. If the finally used port is not the one
handled by neutron, the guest VM will have no network access.
The solution is to change nova xenapi to add a bridge, which
we call the 'interim bridge', between the VM and the OVS
integration bridge. In this way it will only expose to neutron
with the integration bridge's port which connected to the
interim bridge. So it will fix the issue mentioned above.

Closes-Bug: #1268955

Add 1M room to let parted align partitions

fuel-agent always uses optimal alignment for partitions and
thoroughly relies on parted to perform that aligning. (-a optimal)

The issue is that under certain circumstances due to that alignment,
the end of particular partition could cross 1M boundary. And due to
actual partition' bounderies being rounded up, fuel-agent mistakenly
assumes that partition couldn't fit within provided boundaries and
raises errors.WrongPartitionSchemeError.

Adding 1M gap between to the next beginning of partition resolves
described issue.

subject: [WIP] Basic trunk L2 agent extension for the OVS agent
commit_message:
[WIP] Basic trunk L2 agent extension for the OVS agent

Currently this patch is only for illustration purposes.

When Nova/os-vif creates the 1st patch port pair from a trunk bridge to
br-int, this L2 agent extension is triggered and creates the patch port
pairs necessary for the trunk's subports. When Nova/os-vif deletes the
1st patch port pair, this L2 agent extension is triggered to remove the
trunk's subport patch pairs.

When creating the patch port pairs for the subports, the extension is
not responsible for adding the local vlan tag on the br-int patch ports
(and other required port config). This is handled by the core of the OVS
agent when it detects that new ports have been added to br-int. The
ports that correspond to subports must be bound in order for the OVS
agent to complete the OVS port config on br-int. Otherwise, the OVS
agent will consider these subport patch ports to be "dead" and won't
complete their configuration.

subject: Support LLDP data as part of interfaces in inventory
commit_message:
Support LLDP data as part of interfaces in inventory

To support multi-tenant networking in Ironic we need to be able to
discover not just the NICs a baremetal machine has but also the physical
connectivity to switches in the network.

This patch collects LLDP (Link Layer Discovery Protocol) data as part of
the list interfaces stage of the generic hardware manager. This
information can then be processed by the ironic inspector to populate
the local link information on each ironic port.

The processing done on this data in ironic python agent is limited, this
is to allow for server side processing hooks to process as much or as
little of the data as they want. This is to allow for multi-vendor
environments that might use different parts of the LLDP packet to use a
generic ramdisk and configure the processing server side using inspector
plugins.

Reserved fields switch_port_descr and switch_chassis_descr have been
deprecated for removal in Ocata in favor of passing the whole packet.

subject: Do not prompt for scope options with default scoped tokens
commit_message:
Do not prompt for scope options with default scoped tokens

This changes the scope validation to occur after a token has already
been created.

Previous flow:

1. Validate authentication options.
2. Validate authorization options if the command requires a scope.
3. Create a token (using authentication + authorization options)
4. Run command.

This means that scope was being checked, even if a default scope was
applied in step 3 by Keystone.

New flow:

1. Validate authentication options.
2. Create token (using authentication + authorization options)
3  Validate authorization options if the command requires a scope and
   the token is not scoped.
4. Run command.

Change-Id: Idae368a11249f425b14b891fc68b4176e2b3e981

subject: configure keystone with apache
commit_message:
configure keystone with apache

Allow configuration of keystone with Apache via environement variable.
Below are the reasons why we need Apache:

1.  Keystone federation support requires Apache. Federation can only be
supported in conjunction with Apache as it needs both mod_mellon and mod_shib.

2. Performance. Unlike Nova or Swift, Keystone is using eventlet with a
single thread instead of multiple worker processes. So can't take
advantage of multi core node.  Apache give us the flexibility to run
multiple threads and multiple processes, and therefore much better
throughput. Though there are effects underway to make Keystone a
multi-worker process, those changes has not been landed and may
take time to mature.

3. SSL Authorization. Support for client certs.  Since SSL client
certificate already authenticate a given service, there's no need
for service to use a service token to validate user tokens. We simply
map the SSL client certificate attributes into Keystone identity attributes
to form a authorization context for API authorization.  Eventlet's SSL
capability is inferior to Apache by far! You can't get the
client SSL certificate attributes from eventlet.

Change-Id: I03a577b7e88c9026e6fc3cd6839b6c75e8072925
